objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to develop a method that combines literature-based insights with data to perform LLM-powered hypothesis generation, aiming to integrate theory-driven and data-driven approaches for more effective hypothesis generation.
objective.evidence: To address this, we develop the first method that combines literature-based insights with data to perform LLM-powered hypothesis generation.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap of whether theory-driven and data-driven approaches to hypothesis generation can complement each other, as it remains an open question.
knowledge_gap.evidence: While both have proven effective in generating novel and plausible hypotheses, it remains an open question whether they can complement each other.

answer: The integration of literature-based and data-driven hypothesis generation is novel, providing a comprehensive framework.
The introduction of a literature-based hypothesis agent that interacts with a data-driven hypothesis agent is a new approach.
The paper conducts the first human evaluation to assess the utility of LLM-generated hypotheses in assisting human decision-making.
evidence: We propose the first approach to using both literature information and data for LLM-powered hypothesis generation.
This agent interacts with the data-driven hypothesis agent (HYPOGENIC), refining and maintaining a shared pool of hypotheses through continuous collaboration.
We conduct the first human evaluation to test the utility of LLM-generated hypotheses and demonstrate consistent improvements on two challenging tasks.

performance_summary.summary: The proposed method outperformed baselines by 8.97% over few-shot, 15.75% over literature-based alone, and 3.37% over data-driven alone in accuracy on out-of-distribution datasets.
performance_summary.evidence: Automatic evaluation results show that integrating literature and data outperforms other baselines: 8.97% over few-shot, 15.75% over literature-based alone, and 3.37% over data-driven alone in accuracy on out-of-distribution datasets.
